senses.definition: ordinary; with no special features

usually; very often; by most people

senses.definition: a message, letter or phone call

senses.definition: containing one main part (= the root of a word or main clause of a sentence) and one or more other parts (called affixes or subordinate clauses)

examples.x: In the complex sentence, ‘I'd like to go to the beach, if it's warm enough’, ‘I'd like to go to the beach’ is the main clause, and ‘if it's warm enough’ is the subordinate clause.

senses.definition: a group of buildings of a similar type together in one place

examples.x: a sports/leisure/shopping complex
an industrial complex (= a site with many factories)
an apartment complex
a housing complex

senses.definition: a group of things that are connected

examples.x: This is just one of a whole complex of issues.

senses.definition: a set of beliefs or fears, which may not be conscious, that can make somebody very unhappy or cause a mental illness

examples.x: He suffers from a guilt complex.

senses.definition: a feeling of worry or embarrassment about something that is not necessary or reasonable

examples.x: She has a complex about her big ears.

senses.definition: the state of being formed of many parts; the state of being difficult to understand

examples.x: the increasing complexity of modern telecommunication systems

senses.definition: the features of a problem or situation that are difficult to understand

examples.x: the complexities of the system

senses.definition: the practice of obeying rules or requests made by people in authority

examples.x: procedures that must be followed to ensure full compliance with the law

senses.definition: the quality of being too willing to agree with somebody or do what they want

examples.x: He was appalled by his parents' unquestioning compliance with the regime.

senses.definition: made of many different things or parts that are connected; difficult to understand

senses.definition: a thing that makes a situation more complicated or difficult

senses.definition: a new problem or illness that makes treatment of a previous one more complicated or difficult

senses.definition: to obey a rule, an order, etc.; to meet particular standards

examples.x: They refused to comply with the UN resolution.

senses.definition: one of several parts of which something is made

examples.x: the different organizations involved in the design of the various components

senses.definition: to write music

examples.x: Mozart composed his last opera shortly before he died.
music specially composed for the occasion

senses.definition: to write a letter, etc. usually with a lot of care and thought

examples.x: She composed a letter of protest.

senses.definition: to combine together to form a whole

examples.x: Ten people compose the committee.

senses.definition: to manage to control your feelings or expression

examples.x: Emma frowned, making an effort to compose herself.

senses.definition: a person who writes music, especially classical music

examples.x: Verdi was a prolific composer of operas.

senses.definition: the different parts that something is made of; the way in which the different parts are organized

examples.x: the chemical composition of the soil
the composition of the board of directors

senses.definition: a short text that is written as a school exercise; a short essay

examples.x: a composition on the effects of crime

senses.definition: a piece of music or art, or a poem

examples.x: one of Beethoven’s finest compositions

senses.definition: the act of composing something, especially a piece of music; the art of writing music

examples.x: pieces performed in the order of their composition
to study composition

senses.definition: the arrangement of people or objects in a painting or photograph
a thing consisting of two or more separate things combined together

examples.x: compounds derived from rainforest plants
The air smelled like a compound of diesel and petrol fumes.

senses.definition: a substance formed by a chemical reaction of two or more elements in fixed amounts relative to each other

examples.x: Common salt is a compound of sodium and chlorine.

senses.definition: a noun, an adjective or a verb made of two or more words or parts of words, written as one or more words, or joined by a hyphen. Travel agent, dark-haired and bathroom are all compounds.

examples.x: Most compound nouns form their plurals in the usual way.

senses.definition: an area surrounded by a fence or wall in which a factory or other group of buildings stands

examples.x: life inside the prison compound

senses.definition: including all, or almost all, the items, details, facts, information, etc., that may be involved

examples.x: a comprehensive list of addresses

senses.definition: designed for students of all abilities in the same school
gained or lost by a large amount

examples.x: The cricket team finished the season with a comprehensive victory over their rivals.

senses.definition: to have somebody/something as parts or members

examples.x: The collection comprises 327 paintings.

senses.definition: to be the parts or members that form something

senses.definition: an agreement made between two people or groups in which each side gives up some of the things they want so that both sides are happy at the end

senses.definition: a solution to a problem in which two or more things cannot exist together as they are, in which each thing is reduced or changed slightly so that they can exist together

examples.x: This model represents the best compromise between price and quality.

senses.definition: the act of reaching a compromise

examples.x: Compromise is an inevitable part of life.

senses.definition: to give up some of your demands in order to reach an agreement after disagreeing with somebody

examples.x: Neither side is prepared to compromise.

senses.definition: to do something that is against your principles or does not reach standards that you have set

senses.definition: to cause somebody/something/yourself to be in danger or to be suspected of something, especially by acting in a way that is not very sensible

examples.x: She had already compromised herself by accepting his invitation.

senses.definition: to cause something to be in danger of attack or of working less well

examples.x: Users perform tasks every day that can compromise the security of their computers.

senses.definition: that must be done because of a law or a rule

examples.x: English is a compulsory subject at this level.

examples.cf: it is compulsory (for somebody/something) to do something
examples.x: It is compulsory for all motorcyclists to wear helmets.

senses.definition: to calculate something

examples.x: The losses were computed at £5 million.

senses.definition: to make sense

examples.x: That just doesn't compute.

senses.definition: an electronic machine that can store, organize and find information, do processes with numbers and other data, and control other machines

examples.x: a home computer

a computer system/program/network
computer software/graphics/hardware
a computer screen
a computer programmer/user
a computer virus
computer-aided design

senses.definition: to hide somebody/something

examples.x: The paintings were concealed beneath a thick layer of plaster.

senses.definition: to admit that something is true, logical, etc. after first denying it or resisting it

senses.definition: to admit that you have lost a game, an election, etc.

senses.definition: to give something away, especially unwillingly; to allow somebody to have something

examples.x: The president was obliged to concede power to the army.

senses.definition: to form an idea, a plan, etc. in your mind

examples.x: He conceived the idea of transforming the old power station into an arts centre.

senses.definition: to imagine something

examples.x: God is often conceived of as male.

senses.definition: when a woman conceives or conceives a child, she becomes pregnant

examples.x: She is unable to conceive.

senses.definition: to give all your attention to something and not think about anything else

examples.x: I can't concentrate with all that noise going on.

senses.definition: to bring something together in one place

examples.x: Power is largely concentrated in the hands of a small elite.

senses.definition: to increase the strength of a substance by reducing its volume, for example by boiling it
the ability to direct all your effort and attention on one thing, without thinking of other things

examples.x: This book requires a great deal of concentration.

senses.definition: the process of people directing effort and attention on a particular thing

examples.x: He stressed the need for greater concentration on environmental issues.

senses.definition: a lot of something in one place

examples.x: a concentration of industry in the north of the country

senses.definition: the amount of a substance in a liquid or in another substance

examples.x: glucose concentrations in the blood

senses.definition: an idea or a principle that is connected with something abstract

examples.x: the concept of social class
helping students grasp abstract concepts such as leadership and teamwork
basic/fundamental/key/core concepts
the concept that everyone should have equality of opportunity
the concepts behind an artist's work

senses.definition: an idea for something new

examples.x: a novel/innovative concept
an exciting new concept in city living
a novel marketing concept

senses.definition: an understanding or a belief of what something/somebody is or what something/somebody should be

senses.definition: the process of forming an idea or a plan

examples.x: The plan was brilliant in its conception but failed because of lack of money.

senses.definition: a desire to protect and help somebody/something

deep/genuine/real concern

senses.definition: something that is important to a person, an organization, etc.

senses.definition: something that is your responsibility or that you have a right to know about

senses.definition: a company or business

senses.definition: a business or an activity that is making a profit and is expected to continue to do well

senses.definition: to affect somebody/something; to involve somebody/something

senses.definition: to take an interest in something

senses.definition: worried and feeling concern about something/somebody

examples.x: Concerned citizens can have a huge impact.
concerned parents/residents/parents/locals

senses.definition: to think it is important to do something

a fundraising concert for tsunami victims
a concert hall

senses.definition: working together with somebody/something

senses.definition: made of concrete

senses.definition: based on facts, not on ideas or guesses

senses.definition: a concrete object is one that you can see and feel

senses.definition: a statement admitting something that you are ashamed or embarrassed about; the act of making such a statement

senses.definition: a private statement to a priest about the bad things that you have done; an occasion when you make such a statement

senses.definition: a statement of your religious beliefs, principles, etc.

senses.definition: the feeling that you can trust, believe in and be sure about the abilities or good qualities of somebody/something

senses.definition: a belief in your own ability to do things and be successful

senses.definition: the feeling that you are certain about something

senses.definition: a secret that you tell somebody

senses.definition: to be trusted with somebody’s secrets

senses.definition: to tell somebody secrets and personal information about yourself

examples.x: She took me into her confidence and told me about the problems she was facing.

senses.definition: feeling sure about your own ability to do things and be successful

senses.definition: feeling certain that something will happen in the way that you want or expect

senses.definition: an arrangement of the parts of something or a group of things; the form or shape that this arrangement produces

senses.definition: the equipment and programs that form a computer system and the way that these are set up to run

senses.definition: to keep somebody/something inside the limits of a particular activity, subject, area, etc.

senses.definition: to have to stay in bed, in a wheelchair, etc.

to confirm a diagnosis/report
to confirm results/findings

senses.definition: to make somebody feel or believe something even more strongly

senses.definition: to perform the Christian or Jewish ceremony of confirmation

senses.definition: a statement, letter, etc. that shows that something is true, correct or definite

examples.x: I'm still waiting for confirmation of the test results.

senses.definition: a ceremony at which a person becomes a full member of the Christian Church

examples.x: a confirmation service

senses.definition: a Jewish ceremony similar to a bar mitzvah or bat mitzvah but usually for young people over the age of 16

examples.cf: conflict between A and B (over something)

senses.definition: a violent situation or period of fighting between two countries

examples.x: armed/military conflict

international efforts to find a peaceful solution to the conflict
This isolated state faces the risk of another violent conflict with its neighbour.

examples.cf: conflict between A and B (over something)
examples.x: A conflict between the two countries could easily spread across the whole region.

senses.definition: a situation in which there are ideas, opinions, feelings or wishes that are opposed to each other; a situation in which it is difficult to choose

examples.x: Her diary was a record of her inner conflict.

senses.definition: to deal with a problem or difficult situation

senses.definition: to face somebody so that they cannot avoid seeing and hearing you, especially in an unfriendly or dangerous situation

senses.definition: to have something in front of you that you have to deal with or react to

senses.definition: a situation in which there is anger between people or groups who disagree because they have different opinions

senses.definition: to make somebody unable to think clearly or understand something

senses.definition: to think wrongly that somebody/something is somebody/something else

senses.definition: not clear or easy to understand

senses.definition: difficult to understand; not clear

a confusing situation/experience
confusing messages/signals

examples.cf: it is confusing (for/to somebody) to do something

senses.definition: a state of not being certain about what is happening, what you should do, what something means, etc.

senses.definition: a group or collection of people, animals or things

senses.definition: to hit somebody/something

senses.definition: the state of being aware of something

Each player folds the paper so that the next player cannot see what is already written. The result is a number of crazy and often funny stories. The stories follow a pattern that always begins with the names of two people and ends with the sentence 'And the consequence was…’

You can copy the data to your new laptop in the usual way.

All the files were copied onto memory sticks.
Use the clipboard to copy and paste information from websites.

examples.cf: copy something from something into/onto something
examples.x: She copied all the addresses from the website into her address book.

senses.definition: to behave or do something in the same way as somebody else

examples.x: She copies everything her sister does.
Their tactics have been copied by other terrorist organizations.
He was just a little kid copying his idol.

senses.definition: to cheat in an exam, school work, etc. by writing what somebody else has written and pretending it is your own work

examples.x: He was punished by his teacher for copying in the exam.
She was caught copying off another student.
Copying other students' work is not acceptable.

senses.definition: to make a photocopy of something

examples.x: Finally, the notes can be copied and distributed to the audience.

senses.definition: if a person or an organization holds the copyright on a piece of writing, music, etc., they are the only people who have the legal right to publish, broadcast, perform it, etc., and other people must ask their permission to use it or any part of it

examples.x: Copyright protects your work from being commercially exploited by someone else without your consent.
The publishers wrote to him about obtaining the copyrights.
They were sued for breach/infringement of copyright.
Who owns the copyright on this song?
His work is now out of copyright.
The songs remain in copyright.

senses.definition: most important; main or essential

examples.x: core subjects (= subjects that all the students have to study) such as English and mathematics
the core curriculum
We need to concentrate on our core business.
The government's proposed solution fails to address the core issue.
The use of new technology is core to our strategy.

senses.definition: used to describe the most important or central beliefs, etc. of a person or group

examples.x: core beliefs/principles

senses.definition: used to describe the most important members of a group

examples.x: The team is built around a core group of players.

senses.definition: the most important or central part of something

examples.x: This report goes to the core of the argument.
Dutch paintings form the core of the collection.
Concern for the environment is at the core of our policies.
Our need for love lies at the very core of our being.

senses.definition: the central part of an object

examples.x: the earth’s core
the core of a nuclear reactor

senses.definition: the hard central part of a fruit such as an apple, that contains the seeds

examples.x: an apple core

senses.definition: the muscles of the lower back and stomach area which help you to maintain good balance, etc.

examples.x: Your posture will improve as your core becomes stronger.

senses.definition: a small group of people who take part in a particular activity

examples.x: He gathered a small core of advisers around him.

senses.definition: so that the whole of a thing or a person is affected

examples.x: She was shaken to the core by the news.

senses.definition: a part of something where two or more sides, lines or edges join

the north-west/north-east/south-east/south-west corner

senses.definition: with the number of corners mentioned; involving the number of groups mentioned

examples.x: a three-cornered hat
a three-cornered fight

senses.definition: the place inside a room or a box where two sides join; the area around this place

examples.x: A large desk occupies another corner of the room.

senses.definition: a place where two streets join

examples.x: The wind hit him as he turned the corner.

the big tree at the corner with Hill Street

senses.definition: a sharp bend in a road

examples.x: The car was taking the corners too fast.

senses.definition: a region or an area of a place (sometimes used for one that is far away or difficult to reach)

examples.x: She lives in a quiet corner of rural Yorkshire.

senses.definition: a difficult situation

examples.x: to back/drive/force somebody into a corner

senses.definition: a free kick or hit that you take from the corner of your opponent’s end of the field

senses.definition: any of the four corners of a ring; the supporters who help in the corner

examples.x: Her house is just around the corner.

senses.definition: to support and encourage somebody; to have somebody who supports and encourages you

examples.x: He's been in my corner all these years and I can never thank him enough.

senses.definition: to go across the corner of an area and not around the sides of it, because it is quicker

examples.x: There’s a worn patch on the grass because everyone cuts (off) the corner.

senses.definition: to do something in the easiest, cheapest or quickest way, often by ignoring rules or leaving something out

examples.x: To be competitive, they paid low wages and cut corners on health and safety.

senses.definition: to defend your/somebody’s position against other people
to like somebody/something

examples.x: She's always had a soft corner for you.

senses.definition: in a difficult situation

examples.x: The captain's knee injury leaves the team in a tight corner.

senses.definition: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it

examples.x: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

senses.definition: to pass a very important point in an illness or a difficult situation and begin to improve

examples.x: The country's economy has finally turned the corner.

senses.definition: connected with a large business company

examples.x: corporate finance/profits/tax
corporate executives/clients/sponsors
corporate identity (= the image of a company, which all its members share)
corporate hospitality (= when companies entertain customers to help develop good business relationships)
initiatives to improve standards of corporate governance

senses.definition: forming a corporation (= an organization or group of organizations that is recognized by law as a single unit)

examples.x: The BBC is a corporate organization.

senses.definition: involving or shared by all the members of a group

examples.x: a corporate act of worship in the College chapel

senses.definition: a large business company

examples.x: multinational corporations
the Chrysler corporation

senses.definition: an organization or a group of organizations that is recognized by law as a single unit

examples.x: urban development corporations

senses.definition: a group of people elected to govern a large town or city and provide public services

examples.x: the Lord Mayor and Corporation of the City of London

senses.definition: accurate or true, without any mistakes

examples.x: Do you have the correct time?

senses.definition: right and suitable, so that something is done as it should be done

senses.definition: taking care to speak or behave in a way that follows the accepted standards or rules

senses.definition: used to say that all the things or people who should be there are now there

senses.definition: to tell somebody that they have made a mistake

senses.definition: a change that makes something more accurate than it was before

examples.x: I've made a few small corrections to your report.

senses.definition: the act or process of correcting something

examples.x: There are some programming errors that need correction.

senses.definition: punishment

examples.x: the correction of young offenders

senses.definition: in a way that is accurate or true, without any mistakes

examples.x: Have you spelled it correctly?

If I remember correctly, he was still the prime minister at that point.

senses.definition: in a way that is right and suitable, so that something is done as it should be done

examples.x: When correctly applied, fake tan is difficult to tell from the real thing.

senses.definition: in a way that follows the accepted standards or rules

examples.x: He was looking correctly grave.

senses.definition: if two or more facts, figures, etc. correlate or if a fact, figure, etc. correlates with another, the facts are closely connected and affect or depend on each other

examples.x: The figures do not seem to correlate.

senses.definition: to show that there is a close connection between two or more facts, figures, etc.

senses.definition: a connection between two things in which one thing changes as the other does

examples.x: There is a direct correlation between exposure to sun and skin cancer.
the correlation of social power with wealth

senses.definition: to be the same as or match something

examples.x: Your account and hers do not correspond.

senses.definition: to be similar to or the same as something else

examples.x: The British job of Lecturer corresponds roughly to the US Associate Professor.

senses.definition: to write letters or emails, etc. to somebody and receive letters or emails, etc. from them

examples.x: She corresponded regularly with her former teacher.

the correspondence column/page (= in a newspaper)

senses.definition: the activity of writing letters

senses.definition: a connection between two things; the fact of two things being similar

examples.x: There is a close correspondence between the two extracts.

senses.definition: a person who reports news from a particular country or on a particular subject for a newspaper or a television or radio station

examples.x: She's the BBC's political correspondent.
a foreign/war/sports correspondent

senses.definition: a person who writes letters, emails, etc. to another person

examples.x: She's a poor correspondent (= she does not write regularly).

senses.definition: matching or connected with something that you have just mentioned

senses.definition: a long narrow passage in a building, with doors that open into rooms on either side

examples.x: His room is along the corridor.

senses.definition: a long narrow piece of land belonging to one country that passes through the land of another country; a part of the sky over a country that planes, for example from another country, can fly through

senses.definition: a long narrow piece of land that follows the course of an important road or river

examples.x: the electronics industry in the M4 corridor

senses.definition: a passage along the side of some railway trains, from which doors lead into separate compartments

examples.x: She had considerable influence in the corridors of power.

senses.definition: willing to use their power to do dishonest or illegal things in return for money or to get an advantage

examples.x: It was seen as the only way to overthrow a corrupt regime.

one of the most notoriously corrupt city councils

senses.definition: not honest or moral

senses.definition: containing changes or faults, and no longer in the original state

senses.definition: the act or effect of making somebody change from moral to immoral standards of behaviour

senses.definition: for only the amount of money that is needed to make or get something, without any profit being added on

senses.definition: to manage the rate or quantity of something so that it does not increase too much within a short period of time

examples.x: These measures are intended to flatten the curve of new infections in order to reduce the load on hospitals.

senses.definition: to move or make something move in the shape of a curve; to be in the shape of a curve

examples.x: a curving staircase
gently curving streets
The road curved around the bay.
The ball curved through the air.
His lips curved in a smile.
A smile curved his lips.

senses.definition: having a round shape

examples.x: a curved edge/surface
a curved display/screen
a gently curved bay
A ball follows a curved path as it travels through the air.
The central space has a curved roof that spans 21 m.
The knife has a curved blade.

senses.definition: the legal right or duty to take care of or keep somebody/something; the act of taking care of something/somebody

examples.x: Who will have custody of the children?
The parents were given joint custody of the two children.
The divorce court awarded custody to the child's mother.
The parents were locked in a bitter battle for custody.
The bank provides safe custody for valuables.
The castle is now in the custody of the state.

senses.definition: the state of being in prison, especially while waiting for trial

examples.x: After the riot, 32 people were taken into police custody.
He was remanded in custody, charged with the murder of a policeman.

senses.definition: an accepted way of behaving or of doing things in a society or a community

examples.x: It's a local custom.
an ancient custom
a burial/marriage custom
a tribal custom
She grew up with Chinese customs and traditions.
According to custom, one son inherited all the family property.
Widows observed the custom of wearing black.

examples.cf: it is the custom for somebody to do something
examples.x: It is the custom in that country for women to marry young.

senses.definition: the way a person always behaves

examples.x: It was her custom to rise early.
As was his custom, he knocked three times.

senses.definition: the fact of a person or people buying goods or services at a shop or business

examples.x: Thank you for your custom. Please call again.
We've lost a lot of custom since prices went up.

senses.definition: a person or an organization that buys goods or services from a shop or business

examples.x: marketing strategies to target potential customers
The company rewards loyal customers with discounts.
one of the shop’s best customers
They know me—I'm a regular customer.
Improving customer satisfaction is a core company strategy.
The firm has excellent customer relations.
How do you attract new online customers?
Our success is measured by how well we serve our customers.

senses.definition: used after an adjective to describe a particular type of person

examples.x: an awkward customer
a cool customer (= somebody who is always calm, even when in trouble)
an ugly customer (= somebody who may become violent)

senses.definition: a wound caused by something sharp

examples.x: cuts and bruises on the face
Blood poured from the deep cut on his arm.

senses.definition: a hole or an opening in something, made with something sharp

examples.x: Using sharp scissors, make a small cut in the material.
a high-quality blade that gives a clean cut

senses.definition: a reduction in amount, size, supply, etc.

examples.x: tax/budget/price/funding cuts
The company has made another round of job cuts this year.
They announced cuts in public spending.
They had to take a 20% cut in pay.

senses.definition: an act of cutting somebody’s hair; the style in which it is cut

examples.x: Your hair could do with a cut (= it is too long).
a cut and blow-dry
The stylish cut of her hair is distinctively modern and urban.

senses.definition: the shape and style that a piece of clothing has because of the way the cloth is cut

examples.x: the elegant cut of her dress
trousers with a loose cut designed for comfortable wear

senses.definition: a share in something, especially money

examples.x: They were rewarded with a cut of 5% from the profits.

senses.definition: an act of removing part of a film, play, piece of writing, etc.

examples.x: The director objected to the cuts ordered by the censor.
She made some cuts before handing over the finished novel.

senses.definition: a version of something that has been created, especially a film

examples.x: Several scenes had been removed in the cut of the movie shown at the festival.
the final/director's cut
We're working on the first cut of next year's budget.

senses.definition: a piece of meat cut from an animal

examples.x: a lean cut of pork
cheap cuts of stewing lamb
The recipe calls for a good lean cut of beef.

senses.definition: better than somebody/something

examples.x: His latest novel is a cut above the rest.

senses.definition: the lively or aggressive way that something is done

examples.x: the cut and thrust of political debate
his cut-and-thrust management style

senses.definition: to reach or maintain the required standard

examples.x: I had to explain to the applicants why they didn't make the cut.

senses.definition: (in golf) to achieve a good enough score to be able to take part in the next stage of a competition

examples.x: Woods needed a 69 to make the cut.

senses.definition: to be included after parts have been removed

examples.x: When a book is made into a movie not every scene will make the cut.

senses.definition: to make an opening or a wound in something, especially with a sharp tool such as a knife or scissors

examples.x: She cut her finger on a piece of glass.
He cut himself (= his face) shaving.
Sometimes people experiencing distress cut themselves (= deliberately).
She had fallen and cut her head open.
She picked up the knife and cut into the meat.
You need a powerful saw to cut through metal.
The canoe cut through the water.

senses.definition: to divide something into two or more pieces with a knife, etc.

examples.x: Don't cut the string—untie the knots.
The bus was cut in two by the train.
Now cut the tomatoes in half.
He cut the loaf into thick slices.

senses.definition: to make something shorter by cutting

examples.x: She cuts hair for a living.
to cut the grass/lawn/hedge
the smell of freshly cut grass
He's had his hair cut really short.

senses.definition: to remove something or a part of something, using a knife, etc.

examples.x: First, cut a long piece of string.
He cut four thick slices from the loaf.
a bunch of cut flowers
I cut them all a piece of birthday cake.
I cut a piece of birthday cake for them all.

senses.definition: to make or form something by removing material with a knife, etc.

examples.x: Workmen cut a hole in the pipe.
The climbers cut steps in the ice.
home-made biscuits cut into heart shapes
Cut a circle of waxed paper to fit the bottom of the pan.

senses.definition: to be capable of cutting

examples.x: This knife won't cut.

senses.definition: to be capable of being cut

examples.x: Sandstone cuts easily.

senses.definition: to reduce something by removing a part of it

examples.x: to cut costs/prices/spending/taxes
Buyers will bargain hard to cut the cost of the house they want.
a plan to drastically cut emissions
His salary has been cut by ten per cent.
The Bank of England has cut interest rates to 1.5 per cent.
Could you cut your essay from 5 000 to 3 000 words?

senses.definition: to allow somebody to escape from somewhere by cutting the rope, object, etc. that is holding them

examples.x: The injured driver had to be cut from the wreckage.
Two survivors were cut free after being trapped for twenty minutes.

senses.definition: to design and make a piece of clothing in a particular way

examples.x: The swimsuit was cut high in the leg.

senses.definition: to remove something from something

examples.x: This scene was cut from the final version of the movie.

senses.definition: to delete (= remove) part of a text on a computer screen in order to place it somewhere else

examples.x: You can cut and paste between different programs.

senses.definition: used to tell somebody to stop doing something

examples.x: Cut the chatter and get on with your work!

senses.definition: to completely end a relationship or all communication with somebody

examples.x: She has cut all ties with her family.
He has refused to cut links with these companies.

senses.definition: to prepare a film or tape by removing parts of it or putting them in a different order
to stop filming or recording

examples.x: The director shouted ‘Cut!’

senses.definition: to move quickly from one scene to another

examples.x: The scene cuts from the bedroom to the street.

senses.definition: to stay away from a class that you should go to

examples.x: He's always cutting class.

senses.definition: to hurt somebody emotionally

examples.x: His cruel remarks cut her deeply.

senses.definition: to divide a pack of playing cards by lifting a section from the top, in order to reveal a card to decide who is to play first, etc.

examples.x: Let's cut for dealer.

senses.definition: to cross another line

examples.x: The line cuts the circle at two points.

senses.definition: to have a new tooth beginning to appear through the gum

examples.x: When did she cut her first tooth?

senses.definition: to make a sound recording on a record, CD, etc.

examples.x: The Beatles cut their first disc in 1962.

senses.definition: to mix an illegal drug such as heroin with another substance
to make a quick or sudden escape
to (not) be as good as is expected or needed

examples.x: He won't cut it as a professional singer.

senses.definition: pretty and attractive

examples.x: a cute little baby
She's so cute!
an unbearably cute picture of two kittens (= it seems sentimental)

senses.definition: sexually attractive

examples.x: Check out those cute guys over there!

senses.definition: clever, sometimes in an annoying way because a person is trying to get an advantage for himself or herself

examples.x: She had a really cute idea.
Don't get cute with me!

senses.definition: an article or a story that you cut from a newspaper or magazine and keep

examples.x: newspaper/press cuttings

senses.definition: a piece cut off a plant that will be used to grow a new plant

examples.x: Take geranium cuttings in late summer.

senses.definition: a narrow open passage that is dug through high ground for a road, railway or canal
a bicycle or motorcycle

examples.x: He was riding his cycle home when he was hit by a lorry.
We went for a cycle ride on Sunday.
Lots of people arrived in cars or on cycles.
They completed their journey by cycle.

senses.definition: the fact of a series of events being repeated many times, always in the same order

examples.x: Every business goes through cycles.
the cycle of the seasons
The argument is that reprisals simply perpetuate the cycle of violence.
They could not break the cycle of harvest failure, food shortage, price increase and misery.
Front runners generally establish themselves early in the election cycle.
The percentage of companies being downgraded was typical for this point in the economic cycle.
different phases of the cell cycle

senses.definition: a complete set or series, for example of movements in a machine

examples.x: eight cycles per second
the rinse cycle (= in a washing machine)

senses.definition: to ride a bicycle; to travel by bicycle

examples.x: measures to encourage more people to cycle
I usually cycle home through the park.
He cycles ten miles to and from work every day.

senses.definition: believing that people only do things to help themselves rather than for good or honest reasons

examples.x: a cynical view/smile
Do you have to be so cynical about everything?

senses.definition: not believing that something good will happen or that something is important

examples.x: I'm a bit cynical about the benefits of the plan.
Her experiences with men have made her thoroughly cynical about love.
I'm a little cynical about her motives.

senses.definition: not caring that something might hurt other people, if there is some advantage for you

examples.x: a cynical disregard for the safety of others
a deliberate and cynical foul

senses.definition: a type of sweet frozen food made from milk fat, tasting of fruit, chocolate, etc. and often eaten as a dessert; a small amount of this food intended for one person, often served in a container made of biscuit that is like a cone in shape

examples.x: Desserts are served with cream or ice cream.
Who wants an ice cream?
apple pie with ice cream

senses.definition: used with the numbers 1 to 12 when telling the time, to mean an exact hour

examples.x: He left between five and six o'clock.
at/after/before eleven o’clock

senses.definition: by, in or for every hundred

examples.x: a 15 per cent rise in price
The company announced a 21 per cent increase in profits.
House prices dropped 8 per cent last year.
Dairy product prices jumped (= increased by)10.4 per cent in April.
Shares in the company are up 1.9 percent.

senses.definition: in every way

examples.x: I'm not a hundred per cent sure.
My family supports me one hundred per cent.

senses.definition: completely fit and healthy

examples.x: I still don't feel a hundred per cent.

senses.definition: by, in or for every hundred

examples.x: a 15 per cent rise in price
The company announced a 21 per cent increase in profits.
House prices dropped 8 per cent last year.
Dairy product prices jumped (= increased by)10.4 per cent in April.
Shares in the company are up 1.9 percent.

senses.definition: in every way

examples.x: I'm not a hundred per cent sure.
My family supports me one hundred per cent.

senses.definition: completely fit and healthy

examples.x: I still don't feel a hundred per cent.

senses.definition: one part in every hundred

examples.x: Poor families spend about 80 to 90 per cent of their income on food.
It is often stated that we use only 10 per cent of our brain.
What per cent of the population is/are overweight?
Sales increased by 5 percent last year.

senses.definition: to put as much effort into something as you can; to give even more effort than could be expected

examples.x: Every player gave a hundred per cent tonight.

senses.definition: used to show that you do not think that the word or phrase that is being used to describe somebody/something is appropriate

examples.x: the opinion of a so-called ‘expert’
How have these so-called improvements helped the local community?

senses.definition: used to introduce the word that people usually use to describe something

examples.x: artists from the so-called ‘School of London’
